episode_summary: This episode of "No Such Thing As A Fish" covers a range of quirky and intriguing facts, including the environmental impact of emails, the origins of the term 'hot dog', a historical recording of poet Robert Browning, and a post-war operation involving parachuting beavers in Idaho.

facts.fact: In Britain alone, unnecessary emails create nearly 24,000 tons of carbon every year.
Hot dogs are called hot dogs because people used to think they contain dog.
The oldest recording we have of a poet reading his own poem is of Robert Browning, who forgets the words to the poem halfway through and ends the recording with an apology.
In 1948 in Idaho, leftover World War II parachutes were used to drop beavers out of airplanes.
